user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_set:
```c
void metal_softirq_set(int irq)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	cntr = &metal_softirq_cntr;

	if (irq < cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= (cntr->irq_base + cntr->irq_num)) {
		return;
	}

	irq -= cntr->irq_base;
	atomic_store(&metal_softirq_pending[irq], 1);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_softirq_set:
static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(metal_softirq_cntr,
				    METAL_IRQ_ANY, METAL_SOFTIRQ_NUM,
				    NULL,
				    metal_softirq_set_enable, NULL,
				    metal_softirqs)
...
struct metal_irq_controller {
	int irq_base; /**< Start of IRQ number of the range managed by
		 	* the IRQ controller
		 	*/
	int irq_num; /**< Number of IRQs managed by the IRQ controller */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to interrupt controller function */
	metal_irq_set_enable irq_set_enable; /**< function to set IRQ enable */
	metal_cntr_irq_register irq_register; /**< function to register IRQ
						* handler
						*/
	struct metal_list node; /**< list node */
	struct metal_irq *irqs; /**< Array of IRQs managed by the controller */
}
...

</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No explicit compiler language extensions are visible in the provided code fragment. The function body uses only standard C constructs: pointer dereference, integer arithmetic, array indexing, conditional, return, and atomic_store. atomic_store is part of the C11 <stdatomic.h> specification (a standard language/library feature), not a compiler-specific extension. The macro invocation static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(...) is a use of a macro name; a macro call alone is not a language extension. The macro definition is not provided here — if that macro expands to compiler-specific extensions (for example GCC attributes, statement-expressions, typeof, inline assembly, or other documented compiler extensions) then the macro definition should be inspected. Given only the code shown, there are no constructs that are documented compiler extensions, so no fragments are flagged for investigation.
